generated_text: The structure of ice II, which is the most stable phase of water at high pressure and low temperature, has been the subject of intense research for decades. However, the structure of the hydrate formed by the enclathration of neon into ice II has not been resolved. In this work, we report the structure of neon hydrate at high pressure and low temperature. Our results provide a new perspective on the structure of ice II and the mechanism of enclathration. They also provide a new route to the synthesis of ice II and the study of its properties. This work is expected to be of interest to a wide range of researchers, including those in the fields of high-pressure science, high-pressure chemistry, and ice II.

We provide a categorical definition of quantum theory. The definition is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. The definition is also a step toward a general theory of quantum systems and their interactions.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals, including humans. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first comparative analysis of the transcriptome and genome of two distantly related myxozoan species, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and compare these to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results provide insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade host immune responses is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and replicate in their host. In this study, we describe a mechanism by which SARS-CoV-2, the causative agent of the COVID-19 pandemic, is able to block nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are critical for induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We show that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this anti-IFN activity. We also show that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and interacts with Nup98-Rae1, a protein complex that is critical for nuclear import. Our data reveal a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and may provide a target for the development of new antiviral strategies. The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. Sperm cells are quiescent in the male reproductive system due to Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 channels, but become active once introduced into the low-Zn2+-concentration environment of the female reproductive tract. How Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet this demand. This study quantifies the impact of climate change on maize yields and yields variability in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase to 86% in the top four maize-exporting countries under 4 °C of global warming. These results highlight the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. They also portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. Our results are important for the design of adaptation strategies to climate change. They also have implications for the stability of global food trade and international grain prices.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa from diet samples. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, species differed in diet composition, and that dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This may have important implications for the conservation of African savanna biodiversity.

We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. Our findings suggest that the crisis is already having a severe impact on small businesses, with many already laying off workers and closing their doors. Moreover, many small businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many small businesses are planning to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is a ubiquitous problem in the open ocean. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of plastic debris in the open ocean, which involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The cosmic ray exposure ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite are determined. The grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This indicates that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This indicates that the early solar system was not polluted by the interstellar medium.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

Reproductive output is a fundamental measure of fitness in all species. It is also one of the most difficult traits to measure, especially in wild populations. Here, we use a comparative approach to understand the factors that increase reproductive output and the strength of the effect. We find that domestication and all forms of allocare correlate with increased fertility. All forms of provisioning correlate with larger litters without compromising offspring size. The greatest increase we observe in reproductive power is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This may have important implications for the evolution of reproduction in domestic animals and the conservation of wild species. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system, the basal ganglia, and the cerebellar cortex. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to preserve their function in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept of the ability of VX-765 to mitigate α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in a mouse model of MSA. This is a major step toward the development of a clinical trial in humans. (Show more)

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to perform a variety of functions. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of cells that are connected to each other in a network. The network is composed of clusters of cells that are connected to each other in a short-path communication network. The communication network is scale-free, meaning that the number of connections between cells is not evenly distributed. The network is also small-world, meaning that the network is both efficient at transmitting information locally and globally. These findings reveal that the endothelial network design is effective for both local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. This may have implications for the development of new therapies for cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health surveillance and epidemiological modelers. We present the COVIDcast API, a data platform that provides open access to a wide range of public health surveillance signals, including traditional signals from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, as well as many auxiliary signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This platform is designed to empower researchers and policy makers to track the pandemic and its impact, and to empower decision-making.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This structural coupling is mediated by an allosteric communication between the two gates. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this Threonine residue is essential for the structural coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for health and well-being. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is only beginning to be understood, and the potential for natural products to be discovered from the microbiome is a rapidly growing area of research. Here, we report the discovery of a diverse array of natural products from anaerobic gut fungi that are likely to be used by the host to maintain health. These results provide a foundation for further investigation into the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to produce novel natural products.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, but the role of personality traits in determining social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders

The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the current design and manufacturing approaches are limited by the restricted material choices and the lack of understanding of the underlying deformation mechanisms. Here, we propose a synthesis and manufacturing strategy to design and manufacture mechanical devices with programmable behaviors. The strategy is based on the inverse design of composite structures composed of multiple materials with distinct behaviors. The structures are digitally synthesized and then manufactured into mechanical devices. The devices exhibit programmable behaviors, including complex shapes and motions, under large deformations. The proposed strategy can be extended to design and manufacture mechanical devices with programmable behaviors for a wide range of applications. It can also be extended to design and manufacture mechanical devices with programmable behaviors under other deformation modes. This work provides a new paradigm for the design and manufacturing of mechanical devices with programmable behaviors.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin levels in the blood are determined by the expression of the globin genes, which are under the control of the BCL11A transcription factor. In this study, we show that the mRNA-binding protein IGF2BP1 is expressed in the erythroid lineage and is able to reprogram the hemoglobin expression in human erythroblasts. This is a remarkable finding, as it suggests that the hemoglobin levels in the blood can be regulated by the age of the individual.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. In this study, we found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through the SREBP1/SCD1 pathway, and that this resistance is associated with sustained activation of mTORC1. In addition, we found that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction resulted in near-complete tumor regression in preclinical models. These findings suggest that ferroptosis may be a promising target for cancer therapy in patients with PI3K-mutated breast cancer or PTEN-defective prostate cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2) blockers (LCCBs). These drugs are widely used because of their efficacy and safety. However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate the STIM/ORAI Ca2+ sensor complex, which is involved in the regulation of vascular remodeling. Our findings provide a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of hypertension and cardiovascular diseases. This study also suggests that LCCBs may be used with caution in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was not successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird species. Our findings suggest that the NWFP failed to halt the decline of older forests and that the creation of early-seral ecosystems may not be sufficient to halt the decline of older-forest–associated bird species.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the scientific community. In this work, we present a rational design strategy for the development of new acylide antibiotics. The strategy is based on the use of computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best candidate was tested in vitro and in vivo, and it was found to be 56 times more active than telithromycin, a clinically used acylide antibiotic. The best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The strategy presented in this work can be used for the rational design of new antibiotics in general. It can be used to develop new acylide antibiotics, which are a promising class of antibiotics

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with a large number of training samples. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. This makes the proposed architecture more suitable for applications in practice.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is a classic example of adaptive radiation, where a single ancestral species radiated into a suite of closely related species. The species flock is endemic to Lake Malawi, and the rapid speciation events that occurred there are thought to be a result of the unique hydroclimate conditions of the lake. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of the hydroclimate of the region, which shows that the lake underwent large-scale changes in size and water level, and that these changes were coincident with the speciation events. The results suggest that the evolution of the species flock was a direct response to changes in the hydroclimate of the region. This is a significant advance in our understanding of the factors that drive evolutionary change. (Show more)

The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. However, the biological effects of these devices on sleep are not well understood. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device before bedtime phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. These results have implications for the design of electronic devices and the timing of their use before bedtime. They also highlight the need for further research to understand the impact of these devices on health and safety. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Younger Dryas cooling is a 1.0- to 1.1-ka interval of global climate change marked by a drop in temperature and a change in the North Atlantic Ocean magnetic signal. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Os concentration in bulk samples and magnetic grains from the YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania is 2.8 pg/g and 15 pg/g, respectively, much lower than that in average upper continental crust (=31 pg/g). The YDB site in Pennsylvania is remarkable in yielding 2- to 5-mm diameter spherules containing minerals such as suessite (Fe-Ni silicide) that form at temperatures in excess of 2000 °C. The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in different systemic diseases remains to be determined. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, in contrast to congenital deficiency, this was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells. However, T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. Notably, cell transfer of thymocytes de novo produced myocarditis, otherwise not observed in donor mice depleted in adulthood. Moreover, CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. These findings provide a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the immune system and its potential as a therapeutic target in autoimmune

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate beetle diversification rates and traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Our analyses resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of an arsenal of genes encoding these enzymes. Our results suggest that beetle diversity resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant cell wall-degrading enzymes. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE2 is associated with decreased AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a molecular mechanism for the role of APOE in AD pathogenesis. They also suggest a potential therapeutic target for AD treatment.

The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is 1,200 km in diameter and 120 km in radius. It is the densest part of the Earth, with a density of 13.0–13.5 g/cm3, which is 100 times that of water. The inner core is a mystery because it is not understood how it formed. This study provides a solution to the long-standing paradox of the inner core formation, which has been a major obstacle in understanding the Earth's interior.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and increased addictive behaviors. These findings highlight the importance of investigating the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain.

We present a large-scale, integrative analysis of human language processing in the brain. We show that the most powerful artificial neural network models for this task are also the best at predicting the brain’s activity in response to individual words and sentences. This suggests that the human brain may be using similar mechanisms to process individual words and sentences. We also find that the models’ neural fits are correlated with their ability to predict the next word in a sequence of spoken words. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing may be a fundamental mechanism in the way the human brain comprehends language. They also suggest that the brain may be using predictive coding algorithms to compute the meaning of language. This is a major advance in our understanding of the human language system.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability is due to the fact that the current DL methods are not general enough. We introduce a new class of algorithms that can compute stable neural networks (NNs) in scientific computing. We prove that the new class of algorithms can compute stable NNs in inverse problems, and we also provide a classification theory for the existence of such algorithms. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the use of DL in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a textbook example of the failure of social distancing. The failure is not due to people’s inability to understand exponential growth. It is due to the failure of a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. The experiment’s critical design flaws are discussed here as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years, and it is still a major public health problem in many parts of the world. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been studied for decades, but the pathogen that causes the reactional state known as Lucio’s phenomenon, which is characterized by the presence of a large number of lymphocytes in the skin, is still unknown. Here we present the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which is the causative agent of diffuse lepromatous leprosy. We also show that M. lepromatosis is phylogenetically closer to the MRCA than M. leprae, and that they have retained many of the same functions despite their ancient separation. These results suggest that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. (Show more)

The dynamics of entanglement and entropy in quantum systems is a central topic of current research. However, a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics is still lacking for interacting systems, which are ubiquitous in nature. Here, we show that the integrability of the many-body dynamics in the space–time scaling limit allows for a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems. Our result is based on a careful analysis of the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, which is complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations. Our work provides a framework for the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems, which is expected to be relevant for a wide range of physical systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The only available vaccine, developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, is not available to the general public. We describe a vaccine candidate that is based on a segment of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein recoded with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. This vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro, but grows robustly at the permissive temperature. In hamsters, the vaccine candidate is more than 100 times less virulent than the wild-type virus, and it protects from lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. This vaccine candidate is a promising candidate for mass vaccination programs. (Show more)

Plague is a disease that has plagued humans for thousands of years. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) is characterized by recurrent epidemics and high mortality, which led to the loss of millions of lives. The vector of plague during the Second Pandemic is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that it was spread by rats. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which was able to fit mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human mortality data for the study of past epidemics.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is still poorly understood. Here, we present a comprehensive dataset of neuron numbers in amniotes, which is the first of its kind. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition. Our results also suggest that the evolution of brain neuronal density may be a key factor in the rise of complex cognition.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial protein that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the role of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. Here we show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin filaments are the main structural elements of the cytoskeleton, and they are also the main targets of the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins. ADF/cofilin is responsible for the disassembly of actin filaments, and it does so by severing them. However, the mechanism by which it does so is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin is able to induce a mechanical torque on filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist. This torque dramatically enhances severing, and we propose that it is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have important implications for our understanding of ADF/cofilin’s role in cell biology. They also suggest that the mechanical properties of the filament network in which ADF/cofilin acts are critical determinants of its activity.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is often promoted as a healthier alternative to glucose, the sugar found in many foods and beverages. However, the relative appetite-suppressing effects of fructose and glucose remain unclear. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and promotes feeding behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a stronger appetite suppressant than glucose and may be a contributing factor to the increased prevalence of obesity in the United States. Future studies are needed to determine the extent to which these findings generalize to other populations, such as those with diabetes. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian and Bantu populations are found in sympatry. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, which allowed us to investigate the origin and the settlement history of the Malagasy people. We find that Madagascar was settled by a Bantu population and a Austronesian population, which were not in contact with each other. The settlement history of Madagascar was also sex biased, with a higher contribution of males from Southeast Asia and a higher contribution of females from Africa. These results provide insights into the human history of Madagascar and help to understand the origin of the Malagasy people. They also provide a better understanding of the human history of the Indian Ocean islands.

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks, and suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, people can be positively affected by observing others’ positive experiences. These findings have implications for understanding the spread of emotions in social networks, and for the design of social media platforms. They also suggest that, in contrast to the assumption that people are largely unaware of their own emotions, people are often aware of the emotions of others, and that this awareness can be positive.

The ribosome is the primary protein-synthesizing complex in cells, and the mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are modified in many ways. One of the most common modifications is pseudouridine (Ψ), which is present in coding regions of mRNA. We show that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can impede the addition of amino acids to the growing peptide chain and the activation of the elongation factor EF-Tu. We also show that the presence of Ψ can increase the rate of protein synthesis from a single mRNA sequence, and that this can be used to increase the rate of translation of near-cognate amino acids on the ribosome. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can have subtle effects on protein synthesis, and that the ribosome can be sensitive to the presence of Ψ. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social engagement, and time use. These findings suggest that a sense of worthwhile living may be a key factor in promoting healthy aging and may be a target for interventions to improve the quality of life in older age.

The evolution of aquatic lifestyles has been a major driver of the evolution of mammals, but the extent to which aquatic lifestyles have driven the evolution of body size remains unclear. Here, we use a model of the energetic constraints on body size to show that aquatic lifestyles are driving the evolution of body size in mammals toward a size attractor of ∼500 kg. This size attractor is consistent with the evolution of three independent body size increases in aquatic mammals and with the evolution of a size-independent body size in the fossil record. This model provides a mechanistic explanation for the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals and suggests that the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals is not yet complete.

The common cold is one of the most common diseases worldwide, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication is a major obstacle to the development of rhinovirus-based vaccines and therapeutics. Here, we show that mouse airway cells replicate rhinovirus more efficiently at the cool temperature found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. This temperature-dependent growth is dependent on the MAVS protein, which is a key signaling adaptor of the RIG-I–like receptors (RLRs). We also show that the antiviral defense response of infected cells is less efficient at cool temperature, which partially explains the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication. These findings provide insights into the mechanism of temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication and may help to develop strategies to overcome this obstacle. (Show more)

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in their surroundings. Here we show that the bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface-adhesion system to sense the environment and regulate its virulence. This mechanochemical model for surface sensing is based on the observation that the activity of the bacterial surface-adhesion system is required for the proper functioning of the sensing system. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of sensing systems in bacteria and the regulation of virulence. It also has implications for the development of new strategies to combat bacterial infections.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades, and the number of pesticides is constantly growing. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and its impact on the environment. We show that the use of pesticides is not well monitored and that the impact of pesticides on the environment is not well understood. We also show that the use of pesticides is not well regulated, and that the impact of pesticides on the environment is not well regulated. This study is a call for action to improve the situation.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is not well understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, a common North American cervid. We also show that the number of deer-to-deer transmissions is likely much higher than previously thought, and that the virus has been circulating in deer for several months before the onset of the human pandemic. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a global problem that is affecting the lives of millions of people. This paper examines the problems associated with the construction of large dams in the developing world and proposes solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins in the brain. The exact cause of AD is unknown, but it is believed that the immune system plays a role in the development of the disease. In this study, we demonstrate that neurons are a major source of proinflammatory factors in the brain, and that these factors are involved in the development of AD. This study provides a better understanding of the role of the immune system in AD, and may lead to the development of new therapies for the disease.

The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for the understanding of the evolution of the domestic chicken and its integration into the economy. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We further argue that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century.

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. The folding of a single protein is a complex process that involves a sequence of steps. The steps are not known for any protein, and the steps are not known to be the same for different proteins. This paper describes a study of the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein. The protein was studied by a method that provides a detailed picture of the folding process. The results indicate that the folding of the protein involves distinct native-like intermediates in distinct steps. This is a major advance in our understanding of protein folding.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on nascent RNAs. However, the predominant Np4 decapping enzyme in bacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that, in Escherichia coli cells experiencing such stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is a key player in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore T cell function and decrease sepsis-induced immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a new perspective on the role of arginine in the immune system and its potential as a target for the treatment of sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly marine. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This information is essential for the sustainable management of the planet.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a system self-adjusts its dynamics to maintain a critical state, where the system’s behavior is robust and insensitive to external perturbations. SOC is observed in a variety of natural and man-made systems, including earthquakes, sandpiles, neural networks, and financial markets. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and thermal management. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, which limit its applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain, which can be used to control its electronic and optical properties. This work provides a new route to control the properties of diamond and opens up new opportunities for its applications. It also provides a new paradigm for the control of bandgap materials. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the development of diamond-based applications.

The study of plant defense mechanisms against fungal pathogens is of great importance for the development of sustainable agriculture. The use of plant-derived compounds as fungicides is a promising strategy for the control of fungal diseases. Here, we report the antifungal activity of a unique structure and mode of action of a plant-derived peptide. The antifungal activity of the peptide was demonstrated in vitro and in planta. The mode of action of the peptide was studied by time-lapse microscopy, and it was shown that the peptide is able to penetrate the fungal cell wall and membrane, and to induce cell death. The results of this study provide a basis for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This is the first report of the antifungal activity of a plant-derived peptide.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the evolution of sex and sexual selection. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Female-derived proteins that associate with sperm are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow. We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a common human bleeding disorder. The mechanism also provides a target for the treatment of bleeding disorders.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that is intimately linked to human health. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which is used to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The database is also used to investigate the impact of the virome on human health. The results of this study will help to elucidate the role of viruses in human disease and health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the Earth’s climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes, such as the influence of aerosols on water cloud droplet formation. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to conduct continuous observations of aerosols and clouds over Beijing, China, to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. The isotopic record of the oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes reconstructed from light-dependent organisms, providing an independent method by which to assess the temperature history inferred from the isotopic evidence. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Show more)

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. They open and close their pore gates to control ion flow. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings provide a new perspective on the regulation of K+ channels and may help to understand the mechanism of K+ channel diseases. (Show more)

Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide, and the development of new treatments is urgently needed. One of the major barriers to treatment is the ability of the parasite to invade the red blood cell (RBC), the host cell. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a number of mechanisms to facilitate invasion, including the binding of its adhesin to the host cell receptor. However, we show that the parasite also alters the biophysical properties of the host cell, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and suggests that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This may provide a target for new treatments. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and thermal management. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, and its mechanical properties are sensitive to strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain, and that its bandgap can be tuned by strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide a platform for exploring the interplay between electronic and phonon structures in solids. This work is expected to advance the understanding of the fundamental physics of solids and to inspire new applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of low ambient humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome, and suggest that dry air may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza-associated morbidity and mortality. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is based on a model of language that is not supported by neurophysiological evidence. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the construction of syntactic structures is consistent with a model of phrase construction, in which each word is merged into a phrase, and that the brain’s activity is best explained by a model that assumes a merge operation. Our results suggest that the brain’s processing of language is based on a tree-like structure, but that the tree is not built word by word. Instead, the brain builds phrases, and then phrases build words. This model of language is consistent with the way in which we speak and understand language, and it provides a framework for understanding the brain’s processing of language.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a key regulator of development and homeostasis. It is also a target of cancer, and its dysregulation is associated with many human diseases. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This study provides a deeper understanding of the mechanisms that regulate the redundant nature of the two scaffolds and may lead to the development of new strategies for cancer therapy.

The brain circuit that promotes overeating is described here. The lateral hypothalamus is a key region for the regulation of feeding, and electrical stimulation of its neurons causes vigorous eating. We show that this circuit is composed of a number of distinct neuronal populations, including neurons that project to the ventral tegmental area and inhibit dopamine neurons, and neurons that project to the locus coeruleus and promote eating. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria would be a major advance in agriculture. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This approach could be used to improve the efficiency of nitrogen fixation in agriculture, and it could also be applied to other nitrogen-fixing systems, such as cyanobacteria in water treatment systems and nitrogen-fixing microorganisms in the rhizosphere. This work also represents a key step toward the development of synthetic biology approaches for the control of other microbial interactions in agriculture and the environment. (Show more)

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its deforestation is a major cause of climate change. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, the Amazon is still losing forest at an alarming rate. We study a community-based monitoring program that was designed to improve the effectiveness of remote-sensed alerts and to provide incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. The program’s monitors were perceived as new authorities with influence over forest management, and the monitors’ patrols were perceived as substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols that suffer from free riding and inhibit timely detection of and responses to deforestation. Our findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are diverse, but all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. The spider’s ears are outsourced to its web, which acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna. The spider can hear without a body, and the ear of the spider is supersized by outsourcing to its web. This provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. The spider’s ear is also supersized by outsourcing to its web, which provides a model for studying the evolution of hearing in animals. This study provides insights into the evolution of hearing in animals and the design of acoustic flow detectors. It also provides a model for studying the evolution of hearing in animals.

The health and climate impacts of anthropogenic emissions are difficult to disentangle, and the relative importance of different sources is not well understood. We use a global model to estimate the climate and health benefits of a phaseout of fossil fuels, and the additional benefits of reducing nonfossil anthropogenic emissions. We find that a phaseout of fossil fuels can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year worldwide, and up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. This is a substantial contribution to the global health burden, and can be further increased by reducing nonfossil anthropogenic emissions. Our results suggest that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels is needed to save lives, restore rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The availability of vaccines is critical to ending the pandemic. We report the design and synthesis of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 that is well-suited for large-scale production. This variant exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. This engineered RBD can be presented on a virus-like particle, which reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that this engineered RBD can be used to design a vaccine that is well-suited for large-scale production and may be used to design vaccines for other pathogens. This engineered RBD can be used to design a vaccine that is well-suited for large-scale production and may be used to design vaccines for other pathogens. (Show more)

The role of ALK in development is well established, but the ligand(s) for the receptor are not. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK-like kinases (DrALKals) are ligands for ALK-like kinases and that this interaction is required for the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish and Drosophila eyes. Our results provide in vivo evidence for the ligand(s) for ALK-like kinases and suggest a role for these receptors in the development of neural crest-derived tissues.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it, Yersinia pestis, has been responsible for multiple pandemics. The emergence of Y. pestis from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a well-known story, but the details of its evolution and ecology during the formative years are still poorly understood. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period, which span a period of 10,000 y. Our results suggest that the plague lineage remained relatively stable over time, with a single lineage persisting for millennia, and that the emergence of the flea-adapted form of Y. pestis occurred in Iberia, a region previously thought to be a late arrival of this form of the pathogen. These data provide a more complete picture of the formative years of plague, and will be of great value for future studies on the evolution of pathogens and their adaptation to new hosts and environments.

This work examines the role of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. We find that women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, hegemonic masculinity predicted less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The agricultural transformation of the 20th century has led to the loss of 80% of the world’s grasslands and the conversion of 80% of the world’s arable land to intensive crop production. This has led to a massive release of carbon (C) to the atmosphere, with the potential to accelerate climate change. We show that the adoption of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems can increase soil C storage and that these practices can be used to mitigate the effects of intensive agriculture on the climate. These results highlight the potential of grasslands to sequester C and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agriculture. This is an important contribution to the global effort to mitigate climate change.

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a risk assessment framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We found that the top 12 ranked wildlife viruses are known zoonotic pathogens, including SARS-CoV-2. We capitalized on the recent wealth of virus discovery data to systematically identify and prioritize targets for investigation. The publicly accessible SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is a key trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms that underlie this trait are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We identify three enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of this pigment, and we demonstrate that the same mechanism is used by two distantly related species that are visited by different pollinators. This work provides evidence for convergent evolution of a key trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular basis for the red color of nectar.

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–7th centuries AD) is poorly understood. Here we present genome-wide data from a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 480 and 600 AD. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly of northern and central European origin, but that women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. This is important because the genetic history of Europe during this period is crucial to understand the processes that shaped the modern European population.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. We used a global cloud-based platform to perform unbiased metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) of undifferentiated febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. Our findings suggest that mNGS can be used to identify a broad range of pathogens in resource-scarce settings.
