The human genome is replicated in a process that is highly similar to that of S. cerevisiae. However, the stability of the replicative holoenzyme is unknown. Here, we present a unique set of kinetic assays that allow us to measure the processivity and stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more stable than its S. cerevisiae counterpart and that it maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results also suggest that the human pol δ holoenzyme is a promising target for cancer therapy.

The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In an effort toward reconstructing RNA-based life in the laboratory, we used in vitro evolution to improve the activity of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can synthesize RNA from an RNA template. The improved polymerase ribozyme can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients were analyzed, and the immune characteristics of patients with severe COVID-19 were identified. The pathogenic T cells and inflammatory monocytes with large amount of interleukin 6 secreting may incite the inflammatory storm, which may potentially be curbed through monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-6 pathways. Tocilizumab, which improved the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients, is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The fungal genus Aspergillus is a model organism for studying metal homeostasis, and the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) was recently identified in Aspergillus fumigatus. The BGC produces isocyanide metabolites that bind copper, and the copper-dependent antimicrobial properties of these compounds were demonstrated in this study. The existence of the xanthocillin BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings provide insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and the control of fungal interactions with other microbes. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is a significant discovery because it is a high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph that is not stable at the present day temperature of the Red Planet. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals, and the amorphous material is a mixture of precipitated silica, leachates, and/or fracture/vein fillings. Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agricultural crops. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are also changing accordingly. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk and to minimize the economic and ecological damage caused by late-spring frosts.

Th17 cells are a heterogeneous subset of CD4 T cells that play a central role in the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is unclear what role Th17 cells play in the development of disease. Here, we show that Th17 cells can directly contribute to the development of colitis by transitioning to Th1-like cells and that they can also support the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease and that targeting both Th17 and Th1 cells may be a useful strategy for the treatment of this disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, but also by genetic risk factors, such as the C9orf72 hexanucleotide expansion. We now report a method to convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced astrocytes. This method enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This will greatly facilitate ALS research and development of new therapies. (Show more)

The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the host microbiota is a key factor in the transmission of infectious diseases. Here, we show that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the tick Ixodes scapularis to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota. We demonstrate that IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall polymer, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the arthropod microbiome and may have implications for vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds, as it is the key to understanding the origin of the modern avian body plan. However, the study of the evolution of the tail is complicated by the fact that the tail is a complex structure that is difficult to study in fossils. Here, we describe a new basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, the pygostylians, and show that this group of birds had a mosaic evolution of the tail, with the tail of the new taxon being derived from the tail of a nonavian theropod.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This phenomenon is called color polymorphism. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green color in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and relies on the same mechanism—the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis, a phenomenon that is prevalent in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study also provides a better understanding of the evolution of color polymorphism in vertebrates.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a key factor in the maintenance of pluripotency. We also show that ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of BCSCs, phenocopying the effect of hypoxia. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a potential target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world, and the first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment used to make these Bibles has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbit, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the source of parchment from the past and may be particularly useful for the study of medieval manuscripts. (Show more)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is still debated, but the timing of the event is well established. However, the timing of the onset of the carbon cycle perturbation that preceded the extinction is still debated. This study provides a precise age model for the extinction and provides a detailed reconstruction of the carbon cycle dynamics that occurred during the extinction and its aftermath. The results provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the excessive immune response and the imbalance of proinflammatory and antiinflammatory factors. The role of retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) in IBD is still unclear. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also find that RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Our study provides a new perspective on the role of RORα in IBD, which could be beneficial to the treatment of IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in the spike protein of currently circulating viruses. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this mutation and show that the mutant spike is more open and may facilitate binding to the receptor, ACE2. These results suggest that the D614G mutation may have a positive effect on infectivity.

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that, under mild assumptions, every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an equilibrium, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. Our results extend to the case of tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden of morbidity and mortality. We estimate that the pandemic will result in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction at age 65 y for the total US population. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of an atom are its most basic properties, and they are fundamental to chemistry. The chemical properties of an atom are determined by the atom’s electronic structure, which is in turn determined by the atom’s electronic configuration. The electronic configuration of an atom is determined by the atom’s nuclear charge, which is in turn determined by the atom’s nuclear charge. Thus, the electronic configuration of an atom is determined by the atom’s nuclear charge, which is in turn determined by the atom’s electronic configuration, and so on. This is the basic chemical model. We show that the nuclear charge is not the only parameter that determines the electronic configuration of an atom, and that the electronic configuration is not the only parameter that determines the nuclear charge. We also show that the electronic configuration is not the only parameter that determines the chemical properties of an atom. This is a major advance in chemistry.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in many regions, but the implications for the carbon cycle are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, as caused by population growth and development, can suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. Our results suggest that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our study highlights the importance of human demography in shaping the future fire regime and the need to consider the role of fire in climate policy. This is particularly important in the context of climate change mitigation and adaptation.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel fashion. We also show that the glycan is required for the persistence of the symbiont, and that its catabolism modulates the pH of the symbiotic organ, which in turn enhances the luminescence of the symbiont. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients to symbionts may be a more general mechanism used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. (Show more)

The study of topics in text is a central problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method that integrates advances in theoretical machine learning with word embedding to model topics in text. Our method, discourse atom topic modeling (DATM), is able to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text. This approach can be applied to a wide range of domains and problems. We believe that this method will be useful to many researchers.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. The identification of the exact origin of the Black Death is a major challenge in the history of medicine. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the Black Death and its impact on human history. It also has implications for the spread of other infectious diseases in the past and in the future.

Asteroids are a keystone species in the Northeast Pacific Ocean, playing a crucial role in the ecosystem. In the last 2 y, a disease has caused the mass mortality of at least 20 species of asteroids. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation of the body. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is present in the plankton, sediments, and in nonasteroid echinoderms. The virus is also present in museum specimens of asteroids from 1942, suggesting that it has been present on the North American Pacific Coast for at least 72 y.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. The IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian language family is spoken, and it is the only island in the world where the Bantu language family is spoken. We present a high-resolution genomic map of Madagascar, which reveals that the Austronesian and Bantu populations are not a single, homogeneous population, but rather are composed of multiple, genetically distinct groups. These results provide a better understanding of the human history of Madagascar and will be useful for the conservation of the island’s biodiversity.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our work provides a proof of concept for the use of deep learning in antibody engineering and its potential application to the development of next-generation therapeutics.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status, but their assessments are subjective and difficult to aggregate. We propose a method to convert the original categorical crop expert assessments into a continuous probabilistic variable that is more suitable for quantitative analysis. We show that the resulting crop condition index is robust across crops, exhibits long-term stability, and has nation-wide validity. We demonstrate that the index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results suggest that crop experts can be used as a valuable source of information for agricultural monitoring, and that the proposed method can be used to improve the accuracy of agricultural forecasts. This will be of particular importance in the context of climate change, where the need for early warning systems is paramount.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rates of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The response of soil respiration to climate warming is a key uncertainty in predicting the magnitude of future changes in the global carbon cycle. Despite decades of research, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. Here, we present the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, because it is marked by a lack of fossil evidence. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition from autotrophy to parasitism is accompanied by a stepwise relaxation of functional constraints on plastid genes. Our findings suggest that the transition from autotrophy to parasitism is accompanied by a stepwise relaxation of functional constraints on plastid genes. This is a major finding, because it provides a molecular explanation for the origin of the obligate parasitic lifestyle. It also suggests that the transition from autotrophy to parasitism is accompanied by a stepwise relaxation of functional constraints on plastid genes. The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate change. We use a high-resolution climate model to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for policy makers and stakeholders in SSA, as well as for the scientific community, which needs to be aware of the implications of anthropogenic climate change for the region. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the field of materials science. However, the conditions under which they are formed are not fully understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, provides a link between the discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the creation of the first nuclear bomb.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. Here, we show that the two classes of the enzyme are evolutionarily related, and that a third class exists in bacteria. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of this important reaction. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. In this study, we investigated the roles of ASK1 in the cell-type–specific glial cells during EAE. We found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a greater role in the later stage of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the roles of ASK1 in the glial cells and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits that occurred when conditions were warm were more than twice as likely to yield drought years. We also find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California. Our results have important implications for water resources management and climate change adaptation in California and elsewhere.

Autism is a complex disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the converging functions of autism-risk genes and may facilitate the identification of the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also serves to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling, and dysregulation of its function is associated with a variety of diseases. Here, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and ORAI1 that result in constitutive activation of the CRAC channel, and in patients with Stormorken syndrome, we show that these mutations lead to bleeding diathesis and thrombocytopenia. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this propagation are poorly understood. Here we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that protein aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, and we show that they are responsible for the non–cell-autonomous spread of disease. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the study of the mechanisms underlying the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system and its potential as a target for the treatment of autoimmune diseases. This study provides deeper insight into the role of MTX in the immune system and its potential as a target for the treatment of autoimmune diseases. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. We have developed a series of small-molecule inhibitors of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. We show that these inhibitors are effective in vitro and in vivo, and that they are particularly effective in B-cell cancers. We also show that one-carbon unit deficiency is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, this work provides a metabolic rationale for targeting SHMT in cancer, and a metabolic target for the treatment of one of the most aggressive cancers. This work also provides a proof-of-concept for the use of one-carbon unit inhibitors as a class of cancer therapeutics.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations that affect a number of proteins. These proteins are highly aggregation-prone and form characteristic inclusions in the brain and spinal cord. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystals can be used to control the interactions between atoms, and the optical tweezers can be used to control the placement of atoms. These devices can be used to study many-body physics, quantum simulation, and quantum engineering.

The Cretaceous is often considered to be a time of great diversification of plants. However, the origin of the most important lineages of plants is poorly understood. The study of the aquatic plant Montsechia, first recovered from the Cretaceous of the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago, provides new insights into the origin of the angiosperms. Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum, a group that is considered to be sister to eudicots. This result suggests that the origin of the angiosperms was more complex than previously thought and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in the field of virology, but it is difficult to study because of the lack of genetic material from ancient times. Here we present the first ancient viral sequences, which are from dental and skeletal remains of humans from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

This study provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is in agreement with the rate of sea level rise over the same period as determined by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that pain has increased more for those born after 1950 than for those born after 1920. This pattern is seen across the education spectrum, but is most pronounced for those with less education.

The ability to characterize the structure and dynamics of enzyme intermediates is a key goal in the field of structural biology. Here, we demonstrate the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of a key enzyme intermediate. This approach provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the reaction pathway, including the role of crystallographic waters, and highlights the importance of the α-aminoacrylate hydroxyl leaving group in the reaction. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme catalysis. This approach is applicable to a wide range of enzymes and substrates, and will be a valuable tool for understanding the chemistry of enzymes in the future.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a drug that was developed for the treatment of Ebola virus disease, is effective in the treatment of MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This may be of importance for the treatment of other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel fashion. We also show that the glycan is required for the persistence of the symbiont, and that its catabolism is necessary for the acidification of the luminescent organ, which enhances the activity of the symbiont. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms may be a more general mechanism used by animals to regulate the activities of their associated microorganisms. This may be particularly important in the context of the gut microbiome, where the provision of nutrients may be a key factor in the maintenance of host health. (Show more)

This paper reports on a series of experiments and field tests that demonstrate that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. The findings have implications for the future of education, as well as for the future of the criminal justice system.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. We also identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. (Show more)

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions must be cleaved sequentially by two cell-surface proteases to enter cells, but the requirement for these cleavages has not been determined. We found that the first cleavages are required for MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but have little effect on infection into other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Our findings suggest that the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. (Show more)

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change, and is a major contributor to the global obesity epidemic. The food choices people make are a key driver of these problems. In this paper, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a university cafeteria can have a large impact on sales. This suggests that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in the food system could have a large impact on greenhouse gas emissions and obesity. This is a simple and cost-effective way to make a difference. The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment, and the cell surface proteome is a dynamic and complex system. Here we provide a systems-level view of how specific oncogenes remodel the cell surface proteome in a cell autologous fashion. We also provide a glycoproteomics approach that can be used to identify potential drug targets and biomarkers. These studies provide a framework for understanding how oncogenes remodel the cell surface proteome and glycoproteome, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. In the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. However, the effects of vote-by-mail are not well understood. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal costs and may be a valuable tool for safeguarding the electoral process in the future.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people worldwide. The SARS-CoV-2 virus has been shown to be able to evade the immune system, and it is important to understand the mechanisms by which this occurs. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein ORF8. We show that the structure of ORF8 is very similar to that of SARS-CoV-2 ORF7a, but with the addition of two unique interfaces. These interfaces may be used by ORF8 to evade the immune system. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema, a potentially life-threatening condition. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is associated with an increase in the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that, in cultured astrocytes, hypoxia triggers cortical release of CRF, which acts on CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is one of the most important challenges in statistics today. It addresses the following challenge: Having mined a set of data to find potential associations, how do we properly assess the strength of these associations? The fact that we have “cherry-picked”—searched for the strongest associations—means that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. This challenge becomes more important in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. The cherry tree (dataset) can be very large and the tools for cherry picking (statistical learning methods) are now very sophisticated. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, transduced ETV2 elicits expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases ALK and LTK are implicated in a variety of human cancers. Here, we report the discovery of two ligands for ALK and LTK, which are essential for zebrafish pigmentation. We show that these ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized class of photoreceptor cells that are responsible for the production of the blue and green colors in the eyes of adult zebrafish. These findings establish a physiological link between ALK and LTK and demonstrate that the two ligands are essential for the development of iridophores in a tissue-specific context. This work provides a unique model system for studying the function of ALK and LTK and their ligands in vivo. It also provides a potential target for the development of new therapeutics for the treatment of cancer. (Show more)

The role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity has been well established. However, its function in β-cell is still unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus using in vitro experiments. Using silent trans-complementary mutants, we then demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction did not affect the HA titer of the mutant viruses, suggesting that the same amount of viral particles was produced. However, it nonspecifically decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is associated with the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in blood vessels. The atheroprone hemodynamic environment is a key factor in the development of atherosclerotic lesions. However, the mechanisms underlying the atheroprone hemodynamic environment-induced vascular phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions are not fully understood. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by the atheroprone hemodynamic environment is critical for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion formation. Our results provide a molecular mechanism for the atheroprone hemodynamic environment-induced vascular phenotypes and atherogenesis and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and the number of wildfires and area burned has increased substantially in recent decades. This increase is likely due in part to climate change, but the role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. Our results show that human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that the number of wildfires and area burned has increased substantially in recent decades. These results highlight the importance of reducing fire risk to ecosystems and economies, and suggest that actions to reduce human-caused wildfires should be a focus of United States policy.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a group of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insects. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods are still unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne virus that has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. In the case of favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, we predict a dose of 150 mg/kg given twice a day initiated at the time of infection can reduce the peak median viral load by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median viral load by ∼2 d. Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, a single-celled algae, and turn white. The loss of the symbiosis is a major stressor for corals, as the zooxanthellae provide corals with nutrients and protection from pathogens. We show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, leading to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. (Show more)

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the mounting of immune responses, and the prevention of systemic infections. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and stimulate tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and for developing strategies to control tumor growth. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the second leading cause of cancer death. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients do not respond to treatment. We show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy. These results may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the onset of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is one of the most debated aspects of the last deglaciation. The recent discovery of a unique volcanic eruption series at the start of the deglaciation, with a strong link to stratospheric ozone depletion, provides a unique opportunity to test the role of stratospheric changes in the timing of the onset of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce, but are often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also shows that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, particularly in regions where alternative sources of nutrition and employment are scarce. Our data can be used to identify the locations of productive fisheries and the populations that depend on them, and can be combined with socioeconomic and biodiversity data to assess the sustainability of current fishing practices and the risks of future degradation. Our results highlight the critical role of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, and the need to protect these ecosystems from other threats to biodiversity. This will be particularly important in the context of climate change.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable character of Mo-based oxide is the key to achieve high capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are unable to regenerate after injury, and this inability is a major obstacle to the treatment of many forms of CNS damage. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is the major pathway known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of genes that control regeneration in the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the ability to regenerate is not a fixed property of the nervous system but is instead a dynamic process that can be modulated by a variety of factors.

Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and then rewired to create genetic diversity. It is a key process in the evolution of new traits and species. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions showing no evidence of recombination, while others are intensely active. These results suggest that the distribution of recombination is a conserved feature of eukaryotes, and that the initiation of recombination is a more ancient process.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis proposes that the brain is organized into functionally distinct networks, each of which is characterized by a specific pattern of temporal fluctuations in functional MRI signal. This hypothesis has been tested in healthy subjects, but the validity of the RSN model has not been established in disease populations. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN was topographically similar to the default mode network in healthy subjects, but was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern in Parkinson’s disease. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease, but was activated during task performance in advanced Parkinson’s disease. These results provide a direct link between RSN topology and network functionality in health and disease. They suggest that RSN topology may be used as a biomarker of network dysfunction in Parkinson’s disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA, and is essential for proper translation. Here we describe a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We show that NAD-mRNA is produced cotranscriptionally, and that it is found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. These results define an additional 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This may be important for the regulation of mitochondrial gene expression.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. The mechanisms of metabolic memory are not fully understood. Here, we show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in whole blood and monocytes persist for several years after the end of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also provides a possible epigenetic mechanism for the beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. This mechanism may be relevant for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of diabetes complications. (Show more)

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and lacks effective treatment options. In this study, we show that the tumor suppressor protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. We also show that FSIP1 is required for the growth of TNBC cells in vitro and in vivo and that it promotes autophagy, inhibits mTOR and Wnt/β-catenin signaling, and enhances AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) activity. These findings suggest a role of FSIP1 in drug sensitivity and may aid in the design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease that affects the brain, but the mechanisms involved in its development are not fully understood. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with the presence of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota may be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The tomato is a model system for the study of plant biology, and its fruit is a popular vegetable. The flavor of tomato fruit is determined by a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, and the quality of the flavor is highly variable. Here, we identify a gene essential for the production of a large number of the aroma compounds in tomato fruit. The gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of a single precursor, and we show that this pathway is unique to tomato. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato flavor, and will be a valuable resource for the improvement of the quality of tomato fruit. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the conservation of biodiversity and the maintenance of ecosystem functioning in a warming world.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to reflect different aspects of the environment. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is debated, and there is no comprehensive anatomical and functional analysis of this question. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of MEC neurons in freely behaving mice, and we found that grid cells are anatomically distinct from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These data suggest that grid cells form a network that is largely distinct from those of other cell types. Our results also suggest that grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves but have weaker links to other cell types. This study provides a new method for studying the organization of neurons in the brain, and it will be useful for understanding the function of the MEC. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of environmental and developmental signals. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a unique example of the evolution of flowering time in plants. (Show more)

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The precise nature of the pathophysiology of the disease is not fully understood, but it is clear that the system is affected in a way that is not shared by other dopaminergic systems in the brain. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized form of nigral innervation that is specific to Parkinson’s disease. We show that the dopamine-containing dendrites are clustered within the bouquet-like formations, and we suggest that this form of nigral innervation is critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This signal is used by both partners and third-party listeners to assess the quality of the connection between two people. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of language, the development of social networks, and the design of social technologies.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for the generation of the heart rate, and their automaticity is essential for the normal functioning of the heart. However, the mechanisms that govern SAN automaticity are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SANCs and is required for the maintenance of SAN automaticity. Our results reveal that STIM1 regulates SAN automaticity by controlling the content of Ca2+ in the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR), which in turn modulates the activity of the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms that govern SAN automaticity and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of arrhythmias. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increased resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect was associated with enhanced levels of jasmonic acid (JA), a key molecule in plant defense. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote rice defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a better understanding of the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Show more)

The lipidome of macrophages is a key factor in the regulation of many cellular processes. The lipid metabolism of macrophages is also important for the understanding of the role of macrophages in health and disease. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin, a cofactor of the enzyme alkylglycerol monooxygenase, is essential for the metabolism of ether lipids in macrophages. We also show that the activity of the enzyme alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the regulation of the immune response of macrophages. These results provide a better understanding of the role of ether lipids in the regulation of the immune response and of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in lipid metabolism. This knowledge may be important for the development of new therapies. (Show more)

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rates of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Here, we report the successful delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the successful delivery of biomolecules to plants. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be of interest to the plant biology community and will help to advance the field of synthetic biology.

Nutrient loading from small tributaries is a major concern for the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. However, it is difficult to assess the importance of small watersheds because of the lack of data on nutrient loads from individual tributaries. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all tributaries of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. Our findings reveal that small watersheds can be a significant source of nutrients to lakes, especially in nearshore areas. Our results have important implications for the management of nutrient loading to lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. They suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small watersheds, which are often overlooked in current efforts. This approach could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network that is exposed to an environment that makes strong thermodynamic forcing available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the existence of a large number of fine-tuned initial conditions is a consequence of the rare combinations of parameters that make the universe observable. Our results suggest that the same mechanism may be at work in the context of chemical networks.

The mechanisms by which antibodies against the NMDA receptor disrupt its function and cause seizures are poorly understood. Here we show that antibodies change the intrinsic dynamics of the cortex, which in turn changes the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We then show that these changes are sufficient to induce paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in a mouse model of the disease. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDA-receptor antibodies and may help to explain the diversity of EEG abnormalities observed in patients with this disease.
